data.title: Do not display hidden folders in new file manager
data.body: Currently the new file manager (as of 8d618172) displays hidden folders on Linux, which can be bothersome when trying to locate a file in your home directory. It would probably be best not to show hidden folder by default, and maybe to have a CheckButton to toggle visibility of hidden folders.

data.title: Time zone support
data.body:
Adds proper time zone support for the time retrieving functions.
I've tested it for linux, but no other platforms. I don't even know whether it compiles for windows (don't have a win box around).

data.title: connect() should verify the method name being connected to
data.body:
Passing a bad signal name to connect() gives "ERROR: Attempt to connect to unexisting signal: signal_name".

However a bad function name as the third argument goes undetected.  More than once I've had to chase down a subtle typo like forgetting a leading _ in the function name to connect().

Would be nice if connect would verify both the signal and function are valid.

data.title: Numpad 5 doesn't switch camera mode
data.body: According to the menu in the 3D view, numpad 5 should switch between orthographic and perspective cameras, as it does in Blender.  But it does nothing.

data.title: Application often hangs upon exit when using Multi-Threaded 2DPhysics mode
data.body:
Developed (simple 2DPhysics/AnimatedSprites and some custom code testing) application hangs upon exit when the threading model for 2DPhysics is set to Multi-Threaded, tested on windows and android, the problem apparently only happens on the former. Tested with godot 1.1 built from source with Visual Studio 2013 in all of 32bit and 64bit release and release_debug scenarios.

Sometimes, and after a long time (happened quickly once) the output will be something around the lines of "sync ==true" and the application properly quits.

I have already tried doing a lot of customized unload logic such as deactivating the physics server altogether, making sure all existing bodies are asleep and queueing their deletion, blocking signals on both the bodies and the 2DPhysicsSever itself by handling event 7 on _notify, all to no avail; the program still hangs **after** the custom logic runs, I can even go in the debugger and see 0 active bodies for 2DPhysics (but still around 500-ish collisionPairs)

EDIT: Realized that while running from the downloadable release doesn't have this problem, it also does not give the console output for the Multi-Thread 2DPhysics, it's most likely ignoring the parameter and running as Single-Thread.

[image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10016968/8014823/31490980-0baa-11e5-9ae8-169742a8b3d7.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10016968/8014978/77327b4c-0bab-11e5-889d-e10abd635e7d.png)

data.title: Animation player has no animations after instancing scene
data.body:
When I create the scene with Animation Player and some animations it works only if it's a main scene. If I try to load and instance it with:

var scene = load("/scene_with_animation_player.scn")
var instance = scene.instance()
add_child(instance)

the animation player is not working anymore. Debugging has proven that it's missing the animation tracks.

Here are the test scenes.
https://www.dropbox.com/sh/rqnzwgkv6urag60/AAA2ZKvEmx6WYGgp4WoaqNKma?dl=0

data.title: Missing and incomplete documentation
data.body:
Godot's documentation is very spotty and makes learning the engine a very slow, sometimes borderline impossible process.
- The most obvious part is the fact that some features (Light Baking, Editor Plug-Ins) have remained undocumented for **more than a year**. This issue was raised in https://github.com/okamstudio/godot/issues/72, but after promises were made, nothing has changed.
- Another issue is the low quality of existing pieces of documentation. For example, the Physics and Collision (2D) tutorial doesn't explain how to use the collision triggers _at all_, it just mentions their existence and the developer is left to reverse engineer the rest with the use of example projects and forum posts.
- Some code is completely undocumented. An example would be the Path2D and PathFollow2D classes. What exactly are they meant to do? How does the developer use them?

The documentation has to be complete and up to date if the engine is meant to be usable.

data.title: Stereoscopic rendering
data.body:
Since Google Cardbord has appeared, more and more companies produce alike devices to make cheap VR-like experience availabile.

I wonder if it'd be possible for Godot to render stereoscopic images?

Several technologies are availabile:

Side-by-side straigth (for Google Cartboard like mounts) - left eye is left part of the screen, and vice versa.

Side-by-side inverted (for crossed-eye watching) - left eye is right part of the screen and vice versa.

Anaglyph (for oldschool 3D-glasses) - two images with altered colours are blended and displayed on top of each other, tinted glasses filter inmages for left and right eye.

Frame-interlace (for IMAX-like 3D glasses) - the images fro left and right eyes are interleaved in time, and the glasses on user's head dim the eyes to make the images go for left and right eye one at a time.

I can imagine this work for 3D games... and 2D games as well with parrarel backgrounds and overlay layers "popping out".

---

I see playing a game without having a touch interface availabile might be hard, but I've got one idea:

Using the phone with Google Cartboard for VR-like 3D display.
Using laptop/desktop PC as an input device (keyboard/mouse) transmitted via WiFi or Bluetooth to the smartphone.

Hi guys
I'm not sure if the problem is caused by Godot or something else on my system, to be faire. But i'll paste the crashlog here, someone more knowledgeable might give advice.
The external soundcard is Motu UltraLite MK3 Hybrid. It is connected wiht Firewire 400 to my computer (in a FW 800 port, there is an HDD chained - the HDD doesn't seem to be any problem). 
If the soundcard is on ; then Godot crashes on launch. If i turn it on while Godot is running, Godot will crash.
For some time i have been using this soundcard with Godot without problem. One day it began crashing. data.title: Fix Blender DAE exporter - files are unreadable by Assimp
data.body:
Files produced by the blender dae exporter plugin are unreadable by the popular Assimp library.

Colours came though as 3x component instead of 4x component. If colours are in 3-component format, a fourth (alpha) component is silently added with a value of 1.0.

Index of refraction was in the wrong place, it's now inside the <phong> element.

data.title: Inconsistent array behaviour when passed to a function
data.body:
I noticed a rather strange behaviour when dealing with RawArrays (or Arrays, for that matter). Following [the wiki](https://github.com/okamstudio/godot/wiki/tutorial_gdscript_efficiently#pointers--referencing), I wrote some code modifying a RawArray thinking it would affect outside code, since arrays are said to be passed by reference. I found this is not the case:

This is the code I was testing:

``` gdscript
static func set_uint32(buff, value):
   print("in function:")
   print(buff.get(0), ", ", buff.get(1), ", ", buff.get(2), ", ", buff.get(3))

   buff.set(0, (value >> 24) & 0xFF)
   buff.set(1, (value >> 16) & 0xFF)
   buff.set(2, (value >>  8) & 0xFF)
   buff.set(3, (value >>  0) & 0xFF)

   print(buff.get(0), ", ", buff.get(1), ", ", buff.get(2), ", ", buff.get(3))
   print("end of function")

func some_important_function():
   # starts here
   var arr = RawArray()
   for i in range(4):
      arr.push_back(255)

   print("outside:")
   print(arr.get(0), ", ", arr.get(1), ", ", arr.get(2), ", ", arr.get(3))
   set_uint32(arr, 500)
   print("outside again:")
   print(arr.get(0), ", ", arr.get(1), ", ", arr.get(2), ", ", arr.get(3))
```

...which produced this output:

```
outside:
255, 255, 255, 255
in function:
255, 255, 255, 255
0, 0, 1, 244
end of function
outside again:
255, 255, 255, 255
```

This shows the array remained unmodified after the function was run.

As [Brice pointed out](http://www.godotengine.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=12&t=2062#p9795) in [the thread I started](http://www.godotengine.org/forum/viewtopic.php?f=12&t=2062), the code above works if you swap the arr declaration from `var arr = RawArray()` to `var arr = []` and adapt the code accordingly. If you use `var arr = Array()` instead, you're back at the original behaviour.

data.title: add_child error with cross-compiled MinGW-w64 templates
data.body:
I have a Node and a script in it:

```
extends Node

func _ready():
    var cl  = CanvasLayer.new()
    var lb  = Label.new()
    cl.add_child(lb)
    self.add_child(cl)
```

I build to platforms, It work fine on x11 Linux and .exe with Wine, the template .exe I build from MinGW-w64 in my Arch Linux.

But when I run that build on Windows 7 it crash and stopped working.

data.title: scroll wheel event on button not propagated through node2d ancestor
data.body:
Scene setup:  ScrollContainer, with a Node2D child.  Node2D has GridContainer that contains a Panel with a TextureButton.  Scroll wheel events that happen with the cursor over the button do not propogate up to the ScrollContainer.  If you take the Node2D out of the chain, and parent the GridContainer to the ScrollContainer, the scroll wheel events make it to the ScrollContainer just fine, and it scrolls.  Stop mouse is disabled on all controls below the ScrollContainer.

Example:

https://copy.com/meod6XvaHMAzgXUJ
